content: Nirupama Bulusu Nirupama Bulusu Professor of Computer Science Portland State University Home | Bio | Papers | Talks | Students | Service Education Ph.D., Computer Science, UCLA, 2002 B.Tech., Computer Science, IIT Madras, 1997 Awards NSF CAREER Award (2008) Senior Member, ACM (2014) Best Paper Award (industry), PerCom 2019 Office FAB 120-24 (Campus Map, Directions) Email nbulusu AT pdx.edu Phone (503) 725-2404 Fax (503) 725-3211 Follow @nbulusu Mailing Address Department of Computer Science Maseeh College of Engineering and Computer Science P.O. Box 751 Portland State University Portland, OR 97207-0751 About Biographical Sketch 2007 University Profile Teaching Spring 2019: CS 494/594 - Internetworking Protocols Winter 2019: CS 410/510 - Markets, Crowds and the Internet Mentoring Students Advice Service Professional Activities Research My broad research interests lie in the areas of mobile and pervasive computing, cybersecurity, applied machine learning and Internet markets. My research program is highly interdisciplinary and collaborative. Please see papers and talks for more details. I currently work on: Block-Supply Chain: A New Anti-Counterfeiting Supply Chain using NFC and Blockchain (see GameSec '18 and CryBlock '18) Infrastructure-based Indoor Positioning Systems (see Percom '19) Networked UAVs (see DroNet '21) Digital City Testbed Center My past work includes: Mobile crowdsourcing applied to environmental sensing and urban planning (e.g. noise pollution mapping) commerce (e.g. monitoring consumer price dispersion) and personalized healthcare and wellness. Trustworthy Mobile Crowdsourcing and Citizen Science Vision: Towards Trustworthy Participatory Sensing Privacy-preserving Crowdsensing with Integrity Guarantees (SecureComm '11) and Secure Tasking and Aggregation Protocol (ACM TECS '14). Applied machine learning for the Internet of Things (IoT) tracking freshwater plumes in the Columbia River Estuary monitoring invasive cane-toad populations in Australia anticipating client movements and forecasting client demand in retail environments and airports. Network localization Distributed Smart Camera Networks (e.g.3D camera network localization) Ultra Low Power Wireless Sensor Networks network optimization data dissemination protocols distributed data compression medium access control data modeling and code consistency maintenance protocols (e.g. DHV, available as part of TinyOS). In the Public Eye In collaboration with the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, my group created an interactive educational demonstration on sensor networks for elementary school students, which you can read about here.
